keyTakeAways: Colonel Michael Randrianirina, a military officer, led a coup against former President Andry Rajoelina, who had fled the country due to widespread youth-led protests.
Randrianirina appointed businessman Herintsalama Rajaonarivelo as prime minister, citing his international experience and connections with global organizations.
The protests were initially sparked by water and power shortages in September 2025 and evolved into calls for political reform.
The United Nations and African Union have condemned the coup and suspended Madagascar’s membership in their organizations.
The High Constitutional Court of Madagascar ratified the military takeover within hours of it occurring.
Andry Rajoelina denies stepping down, calling claims of his resignation false and accusing authorities of spreading disinformation.
Randrianirina emerged as a visible leader during protests by riding in an armored vehicle, signaling his rise to power.
The coup is seen as a significant disruption to Madagascar’s democratic institutions and governance.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In October 2025, Madagascar experienced a political upheaval when Colonel Michael Randrianirina, a military officer and long-time critic of former President Andry Rajoelina, led a coup following nationwide protests initiated by the Gen Z Madagascar youth movement over water and power shortages. The protests, which began in September, escalated into demands for systemic reform. After Rajoelina fled the country amid the unrest, Randrianirina was sworn in as president and appointed businessman Herintsalama Rajaonarivelo as prime minister, citing his international experience. The coup has drawn strong condemnation from the United Nations and African Union, both of which suspended Madagascar’s membership. The High Constitutional Court ratified the takeover swiftly, signaling the legitimacy of the new government. Rajoelina denies stepping down, calling claims of resignation false and accusing authorities of spreading disinformation, highlighting ongoing political instability and democratic erosion.
title: Madagascar’s new prime minister named after military coup
